channel.description: The sports news portal of TV5

item.title: Take two: San Mig Coffee tries to close out Rain or Shine anew in Game Six
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: The San Mig Super Coffee Mixers will serve the second of three match points when they battle the Rain or Shine Elasto Painters in Game Six of the PLDT Home DSL Philippine Cup finals. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
Sports5/Paolo Papa

The San Mig Super Coffee Mixers will serve the second of three match points when they battle the Rain or Shine Elasto Painters in Game Six of the PLDT Home DSL Philippine Cup finals.

Game time is set on Wednesday at 8 p.m. at the SMART-Araneta Coliseum with live broadcast over TV5.

The Mixers took a commanding 3-1 lead in the series before the Elasto Painters battled to stay alive in Game Five last Sunday behind the hot shooting hands of Jeff Chan.

The Bacolod-born sniper tallied 23 of his 24 points in the second half of that match to help Rain or Shine extend the series.

“Ayoko lang talagang matalo. Ayaw lang naming ibigay ‘tong larong ‘to,” said Chan after the game.

San Mig Coffee superstar James Yap paid tribute to the effort shown by the Elasto Painters in Game Five, but said he has put it behind him.

“Ito yung pinakamahirap eh. Yung (Games) Five, Six, Seven. Yan ang pinaka-mahirap sa championship eh. Yung paano mo i-close yung series,” Yap said after the game.

“Well, nakuha nila yung Game Five, and then focus on Game Six. Move on. Ganun lang.”

custom_fields.related-tags: san mig coffee mixers, rain or shine elasto painters

item.title: NLEX looks to clinch title against Big Chill in Game Two of D-League finals
item.dc:creator: Mikkel Bolante
item.description: The defending champion NLEX Road Warriors will be looking to clinch their fifth title in six conferences while the Big Chill Superchargers fight for survival when they resume hostilities in their PBA D-League Aspirants’ Cup finals series for Game Two … Read more »
item.content:encoded:
PBA/Nuki Sabio

The defending champion NLEX Road Warriors will be looking to clinch their fifth title in six conferences while the Big Chill Superchargers fight for survival when they resume hostilities in their PBA D-League Aspirants’ Cup finals series for Game Two on Wednesday at the SMART-Araneta Coliseum.

NLEX, which has won all but one conference in D-League history, will take on Big Chill at 4:15 p.m. They will be looking to return to the top of the heap after falling short in the Foundation Cup finals against Blackwater Sports last season.

The Road Warriors are riding the momentum of a 79-75 victory in the series opener last Sunday despite not seeing much from leading scorer Garvo Lanete.

Lanete, who was averaging 18.7 points on 49% shooting from the field, was held to just four points on 1-for-8 shooting in Game One.

The deep and talented Road Warriors, though, barely missed his contributions with former Letran Knights star Kevin Alas and Matt Ganuelas stepping up to lead NLEX to the win.

Alas scored 17 points and Ganuelas added 13 in the opener.

NLEX coach Boyet Fernandez, though, remains wary of Big Chill, which has proven its ability to comeback from series deficits to win.

The Superchargers also dropped their semis opener to the Blackwater Sports Elite, 84-72, before winning the last two games, 95-84 and 89-78 to advance to the finals opposite the top-seeded Road Warriors.

Big Chill coach Robert Sison will hope more of his players step up in Game Two, including Janus Lozada, who scored 21 points in their semis clincher but was scoreless in Game One of the finals.

Big Chill’s Reil Cervantes led the way with 17 points while Quinton Heruela added 12.

The game will be televised by AksyonTV, the news and sports channel of TV5, on a delayed basis on Thursday, 8 p.m.

AksyonTV can be accessed on Channel 41 in Metro Manila, Channel 29 in Metro Cebu and Metro Davao; Channel 59 on SkyCable, Channel 78 on Destiny Cable and Channel 1 on Cignal Digital TV.

custom_fields.related-tags: nlex road warriors, big chill superchargers

item.title: Alvin Patrimonio, Yeng Guiao share memories of former Purefoods coach Ely Capacio
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: Yeng Guiao is currently in the thick of his quest to win his first All-Filipino tournament, leading the Rain or Shine Elasto Painters in the PLDT Home DSL Philippine Cup finals against the San Mig Super Coffee Mixers. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
Ely Capacio. Sports5 file/Pranz Kaeno Billones

Yeng Guiao is currently in the thick of his quest to win his first All-Filipino tournament, leading the Rain or Shine Elasto Painters in the PLDT Home DSL Philippine Cup finals against the San Mig Super Coffee Mixers.

The fiery coach is once again battling the same Purefoods franchise that denied him his first attempt to win the All-Filipino way back in 1991.

Guiao’s Diet Sarsi squad lost in five games to a Purefoods team coached by Ely Capacio, who passed away last Sunday at age 58.

“Coach Ely is also a passionate coach,” said Guiao of Capacio, a former player with Tanduay before coaching Purefoods. Capacio later transitioned into a corporate role with San Miguel Corporation before serving in the PBA Board of Governors representing the San Miguel Beer and Petron franchise.

“He knows his basketball and he’s a leader. These are probably the reasons why he got up in the ladder of success was because he had those characteristics,” said Guiao.

The leader of that Purefoods squad, four-time PBA Most Valuable Player Alvin Patrimonio, remains with the franchise as team manager of San Mig Cofee.

“Siyempre yung first All-Filipino championship namin siya yung coach namin,” Patrimonio said about Capacio..

“Maganda yung team noon, but he imposed discipline on the team. Kaya maganda naman yung resulta nag-champion kami.”

That season was memorable for Patrimonio, who won his first MVP trophy that year.

“Dati yung team namin star-studded pero kontrolado niya yung team noon. Kaya nga Father ang tawag sa kanya kasi respected siya,” said Patrimonio.

He was surprised when Capacio abruptly resigned from the team to embark on a management career away from the spot.

“Gulat lang ako kasi hindi niya itinuloy yung coaching career niya. Siguro yun ang calling sa kanya sa corporate world pero successful rin siya,” said Patrimonio.

Guiao said Capacio’s passing also came as a surprise.

“He was very strong and he’s still very young. He’s still at the peak of his mental and even physical strengths. It gives you a reality check. It humbles you, pwede itong mangyari kahit kanino and you have to be ready. Pero sana naman huwag muna tayo kunin ni Lord,” said Guiao.

“But he’s a big part of this league. The fans, the teams, all the people who have enjoyed the PBA, owe him a debt of gratitude.”

item.title: ‘Parang si Bonel Balingit’: June Mar Fajardo has comedic star potential, says Marc Pingris
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: San Mig Super Coffee Mixers star forward Marc Pingris is no stranger to comedy, with no less than the popular Vic Sotto as his father-in-law. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
PBA/Nuki Sabio

San Mig Super Coffee Mixers star forward Marc Pingris is no stranger to comedy, with no less than the popular Vic Sotto as his father-in-law.

Pingris recently starred in a commercial with Sotto for San Miguel Beer alongside other Gilas Pilipinas stalwarts June Mar Fajardo, LA Tenorio, and Japeth Aguilar.

The shoot took two days to complete, giving Pingris insight into the comedic chops of his fellow basketball stars.

Among his three colleagues, Pingris says it’s Fajardo who has the most potential to be a comedy star.

“‘Pag nakita mo, matatawa ka na, parang si Bonel Balingit,” said Pingris.

But beyond his acting talent, Pingris wouldn’t be surprised by any success that comes to Fajardo because of the gentle giant’s kind nature.

“Sobrang bait na tao, hindi siya yung mayabang. Wala, down-to-earth talaga,” said Pingris.

Fajardo just won Best Player of the Conference honors in the PLDT Home DSL Philippine Cup. Pingris was among the first player to congratulate Fajardo for the honor.

But while Pingris is happy for his Gilas buddy, there’s one thing he’s sure he still bests Fajardo.

“Mas magaling pa rin ako sa kanya sa DOTA.”

custom_fields.related-tags: marc pingris, japeth aguilar, la tenorio, june mar fajardo, vic sotto

item.title: Injured Nene out six weeks for Wizards
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: WASHINGTON - The Washington Wizards will be without Brazilian big man Nene for some six weeks as he recovers from a sprained knee ligament, the NBA team said Monday. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
AFP file

WASHINGTON – The Washington Wizards will be without Brazilian big man Nene for some six weeks as he recovers from a sprained knee ligament, the NBA team said Monday.

The Wizards announced the results of an MRI exam on Monday, a day after Nene was injured in a 96-83 victory over the Cavaliers in Cleveland.

Nene was apparently hurt midway through the third quarter, limping as he attempted to get back down the court on defense after colliding with Cavaliers guard Jarrett Jack.

The 31-year-old, in his 12th NBA season, has appeared in 49 games this season, 37 of them as a starter.

He is averaging 14.2 points, 5.8 rebounds, 3.0 assists and 1.2 steals per game.

The Wizards are currently fifth in the Eastern Conference playoff race.

item.title: Knicks cut oft-injured Metta World Peace
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: NEW YORK – Metta World Peace’s return to New York to play for the team he supported as a youngster ended Monday as the Knicks announced they had waived the NBA veteran. The Knicks also released seldom-used guard Beno Udrih, … Read more »
item.content:encoded:
AFP

NEW YORK – Metta World Peace’s return to New York to play for the team he supported as a youngster ended Monday as the Knicks announced they had waived the NBA veteran.

The Knicks also released seldom-used guard Beno Udrih, and both players will be free to sign with any team once they clear waivers.

World Peace — formerly Ron Artest — is a former NBA Defensive Player of the Year and a native of Queens, New York.

He inked a two-year contract with the Knicks in July but appeared in just 29 games this season while battling injuries.

The 34-year-old averaged 4.8 points, 2.0 rebounds and 13.4 minutes per game, the lowest of his 15-year career in all of those categories.

With the Los Angeles Lakers in the 2012-13 season, World Peace averaged 12.4 points and 5.0 rebounds in 75 games.

Udrih, a member of two NBA championship teams in San Antonio in 2005 and 2007, also struggled to find consistent playing time in his only season with the Knicks.

The journeyman guard averaged 5.6 points and 3.5 assists in 31 games with the Knicks, 12 of which were starts.

“We are disappointed that it did not work out for Beno and Metta here in New York,” Knicks general manager Steve Mills said. “We thank them for their contributions this season and wish them well.”

World Peace had a player option for $1.6 million for next season, and was reportedly bought out by the Knicks.

Drafted 16th overall by the Chicago Bulls in 1999, World Peace was the NBA’s Defensive Player of the Year in 2003-04.

The following season, in November of 2004, he was suspended a record 73-games for exchanging punches with fans in Detroit while playing for the Indiana Pacers.

custom_fields.related-tags: metta world peace, new york knicks

item.title: Gary David hopes ‘Kuwentong Gilas’ story inspires younger players from smaller schools
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: PBA scoring champion Gary David was the subject of the second episode of the "Kuwentong Gilas" documentary series on Monday, which detailed his rise from a humble varsity aspirant at Lyceum into one of the top shooters of the Philippine national men's basketball team. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
FIBA Asia/Nuki Sabio

PBA scoring champion Gary David was the subject of the second episode of the “Kuwentong Gilas” documentary series on Monday, which detailed his rise from a humble varsity aspirant at Lyceum into one of the top shooters of the Philippine national men’s basketball team.

David was heartened by the response to his story from viewers, who were enthralled by his rise through the basketball ranks from his beginnings in Dinalupihan, Bataan.

“Salamat sa lahat ng sumubaybay ng aking istorya,” he wrote in a text message to Sports5. “Sana na-inspire ko ang mga players na galing sa hirap at sa mga players na naglalaro sa school na wala sa UAAP at NCAA.

“Sipag at tiyaga talaga ang puhunan, mga idol.”

David’s tale touched the hearts of many fans, who took to social media to express their admiration.

@pbaontv5 grabe! nakaka-inspired ung #KUWENTONGGILAS ni Gary. Gusto ko yung pinagdaanan nya sa Lyceum. Grabe hard-work ni EL GRANADA.

— James Oliquino (@james_oliquino) February 24, 2014

@PBAonTV5 Ung pinagkakasya lang nya ang 10 pesos para sa pagkain nya. Very inspiring. :

— Denisse Mae (@itsdenissemae) February 24, 2014

@PBAonTV5 That part when coach Bai said na ang achievements ni Gary is because of his attitude, nainspire ako dun ng sobra. #KuwentongGilas

— June Sy (@iamJuneSy) February 24, 2014

Kuwentong Gilas airs every Monday at 8 p.m. on TV5.

custom_fields.related-tags: gary david, meralco bolts, smart gilas, kuwentong gilas, sports5

item.title: Marc Pingris relishes chance to shoot commercial with father-in-law Vic Sotto
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: Inside the court, Marc Pingris is fearless when it comes to low post action for the San Mig Super Coffee Mixers. But the star forward admitted getting a case of nerves while shooting a commercial with his father-in-law, popular television … Read more »
item.content:encoded:
Inside the court, Marc Pingris is fearless when it comes to low post action for the San Mig Super Coffee Mixers.

But the star forward admitted getting a case of nerves while shooting a commercial with his father-in-law, popular television host and comedian Vic Sotto.

“Kinabahan ako kahit papaano,” Pingris wrote to InterAksyon.com in a a text message. “But I’m so happy na nakasama ko siya.”

Pingris is married to Sotto’s eldest daughter Danica. The two men are featured in the latest ad for San Miguel Beer along with Pingris’ Gilas Pilipinas teammates June Mar Fajardo, LA Tenorio, and Japeth Aguilar.

For Pingris, the chance to work with Sotto is certainly a blessing.

“He’s very supportive sa akin,” said Pingris. “I feel blessed sa opportunity and sana maulit (joke).”

Curiously, Pingris stars in an ad for a brand that is making its return to the PBA, with the Petron Blaze Boosters reverting back to become the San Miguel Beermen in the Commissioner’s Cup.

San Mig Coffee executive Rene Pardo, however, sees no problem with Pingris appearing in an endorsement for a rival PBA team.

“Hindi naman siguro,” Pardo wrote in a text message. “Pingris like Japeth and LA are from different teams and are talents like in his other commercials.”

item.title: LeBron James misses Heat win over Bulls with broken nose
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: MIAMI - Four-time NBA Most Valuable Player LeBron James was held out of Miami's home game Sunday against Chicago with a broken nose he suffered earlier this week. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
Reuters file

MIAMI – Four-time NBA Most Valuable Player LeBron James was held out of Miami’s home game Sunday against Chicago with a broken nose he suffered earlier this week.

The Heat’s superstar forward torched the Thunder for 33 points to go along with seven rebounds in a 103-81 win on Thursday, but departed late in the game after he was hit in the face by Oklahoma City’s Serge Ibaka on a driving dunk.

It was unclear whether James would be fit to play leading up to Sunday’s game against the Bulls, and Heat coach Erik Spoelstra confirmed less than two hours before tip-off that he would sit out.

“The fact that we don’t play (again) until Thursday, it makes the most sense,” Spoelstra said.

James is leading the Heat with an average 26.9 points, 7.1 rebounds and 6.5 assists in 52 games this season.

Nevertheless, his absence proved little problem for the Heat, who defeated the Bulls 93-79.

Chris Bosh scored 28 points with 10 rebounds and Dwyane Wade added 23 points and 10 rebounds to lift Miami.

Mario Chalmers scored 12 points and handed out nine assists and Ray Allen chipped in 10 points off the bench as the Heat won their fourth straight.

Joakim Noah finished with 20 points and a game-high 15 rebounds and Taj Gibson added another 20 points for the Bulls, who saw their five-game winning streak end.

custom_fields.related-tags: lebron james, miami heat, chicago bulls

item.title: Jason Collins joins Nets, takes court as NBA’s first openly-gay player
item.dc:creator: Jaemark Tordecilla
item.description: LOS ANGELES - Jason Collins took another trailblazing step as the first openly gay man in a major US pro sports league Sunday when he took the court for the NBA's Brooklyn Nets. Read more »
item.content:encoded:
AFP

LOS ANGELES – Jason Collins took another trailblazing step as the first openly gay man in a major US pro sports league Sunday when he took the court for the NBA’s Brooklyn Nets.

Hours after the Nets inked Collins to a 10-day contract, he came in as a substitute in the second quarter of the Nets’ game against the Los Angeles Lakers, receiving the kind of warm welcome from the Staples Center crowd more usually reserved for their own players.

It was the 13-year NBA veteran’s first appearance in the league since he went public in April about his homosexuality, a revelation that came after his contract with the Washington Wizards had expired.

Facing a bevy of media before the game, Collins said his immediate concern was proving he still belonged in the league.

“Right now, I’m focused on trying to learn the plays, trying to learn the coverages, the game plan, my assignment,” he said. “I don’t have time to really think about history right now.”

The Nets ended an 11-game losing streak to the Lakers with a 108-102 wire-to-wire victory.

Collins was scoreless in 10 minutes, 37 seconds on the floor, missing the only shot he attempted.

He had two rebounds and five fouls, and Nets coach Jason Kidd said he was generally satisfied with the performance from a player brought in to bolster the team’s defense.

Nets general manager Billy King said the move to sign Collins was a “basketball decision” to add a defensive presence inside.

“We needed to increase our depth inside, and with his experience and size, we felt he was the right choice for a 10-day contract,” King said.

The Nets can sign Collins to two straight 10-day deals before deciding if they want to keep him for the rest of the season.

Even though King said the Nets had no intention of making a social statement, NBA commissioner Adam Silver commented on the deal.

“Jason told us that his goal was to earn another contract with an NBA team,” Silver said.

“Today, I want to commend him on achieving his goal. I know everyone in the NBA family is excited for him and proud that our league fosters an inclusive and respectful environment.”

Sports world hostile to gays

As part of a sports world still perceived as hostile to homosexuality, Collins drew praise for his courage in coming out as gay by US President Barack Obama, former president Bill Clinton and many players in the NBA.

Los Angeles Galaxy midfielder Robbie Rogers became the first openly gay male athlete to play in a US pro league when he took the field for a Major League Soccer match in May, three months after revealing he was gay.

But Collins is the first in any of the four leagues that dominate the US sports landscape — Major League Baseball, the National Football League, the National Basketball Association and the National Hockey League.

University of Missouri defensive end Michael Sam, a US college star in American football who announced this month he is gay, is likely to be selected in the NFL Draft later this year.

His first chance to play in the NFL would not come until an August exhibition game at the earliest, and his decision to come out immediately sparked debate on whether a gay player could really be accepted in an NFL locker room.

Collins said he agreed with Sam’s stance that he wants to be judged for his abilities on the field of play, and not by his sexuality.

“I hope, similar to what Michael said, I hope it’s about him being a football player and me being a basketball player,” Collins said.

As for advice he would offer to other gay athletes, Collins said it would be the same he offered to any athlete: “Never have any fear to be your true, authentic self.”

custom_fields.related-tags: gay athletes, jason collins, brooklyn nets
